bcl:section.bcl:text: In this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Fish and Seafood Act;
applicant includes an applicant to renew a licence;
aquatic plant culturer means a person who holds an aquatic plant culture licence;
aquatic plant group means a group of aquatic plant species as described in the Schedule;
aquatic plant species means a species of aquatic plant as described in the Schedule;
bivalve mollusc means all or part of a shellfish of the phylum Mollusca, class Bivalvia, commonly known as a clam, oyster, scallop or mussel, whether or not the shellfish has been shucked;
cold storage facility means a facility used primarily for the purpose of freezing fish or storing frozen fish;
commercial fisher means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a fisher's registration card as described in Item 1 of Part I of Schedule II to the Pacific Fishery Regulations, 1993 (Canada),
holds a commercial fishing licence of a category described in Item 3 of Part I of Schedule II to the Pacific Fishery Regulations, 1993 (Canada), or

is designated as a person who is authorized to fish under a communal licence issued under the Aboriginal Communal Fishing Licences Regulations (Canada) and who distributes fish for a commercial purpose;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: container means any form of container or packaging used in relation to fish or aquatic plants;
contaminated has the meaning set out in section 3 (3) of the Act;
equipment includes containers, utensils and any items used to carry out an activity under a licence;
federal licence means a licence or other authorization issued under a federal enactment;
fish receiver means a person who holds a fish receiver licence;
fisher vendor means a person who holds a fisher vendor licence;
food contact surface means that part of equipment with which fish or aquatic plants normally come into contact;
fresh, in relation to fish, means dead but not frozen;
harvest agreement means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a harvest agreement within the meaning of settlement legislation;
an agreement described in section 7 of the NisgÌ±a'a Final Agreement Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: harvest plan proposal means a harvest plan proposal made in accordance with section 10 [harvest plan proposal];
licence, in relation to a licence issued under this regulation, means one or more of the following, as applicable in the context:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an aquatic plant culture licence issued with respect to activities described in section 3 [aquatic plant culture licence];
a wild aquatic plant harvester licence issued with respect to activities described in section 8 [wild aquatic plant harvester licence];
a fisher vendor licence issued with respect to activities described in section 16 [fisher vendor licence];
a fish receiver licence issued with respect to activities described in section 21 [fish receiver licence];
a seafood processor licence issued with respect to activities described in section 27 [seafood processor licence];

bcl:definition.bcl:text: licensed facility means a facility used by a person who holds a licence for the purpose of carrying out activities authorized by the person's licence, whether or not the facility is specifically referenced in the licence;
provincial food enactment means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Food Safety Act;
the Public Health Act;
a regulation made under the Food Safety Act or the Public Health Act with respect to the processing or distribution of food for public consumption;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: seafood processor means a person who holds a seafood processor licence;
transport includes to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: load for transport, and
unload after transport;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: transporter means a person who transports fish or aquatic plants that may be distributed to the public for human consumption, whether or not the transporter holds a licence under this regulation;
wild aquatic plant harvester means a person who holds a wild aquatic plant harvester licence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Fish and aquatic plants present in a licensed facility are deemed to be intended for distribution to the public for human consumption, unless an inspector is satisfied that the fish and aquatic plants will not be distributed to the public for human consumption.
A person must not grow aquatic plants that may be distributed to the public for human consumption unless the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds an aquatic plant culture licence, or
is an employee, acting in the course of employment, of a person who holds an aquatic plant culture licence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to section 7 (4) of the Act, an applicant for an aquatic plant culture licence must include with the application a fee ofÂ $50.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An aquatic plant culture licence expires on the date set by a licensing officer under section 7 (2) (d) of the Act.
A licensing officer may not set a licence term under subsection (1) for a period longer than 10 years.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An aquatic plant culturer must keep records that include at least the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a description of the aquatic plants grown, divided according to aquatic plant group and aquatic plant species;
the quantity of aquatic plants grown;
with respect to each delivery of aquatic plants distributed by the aquatic plant culturer,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the quantity of aquatic plants distributed,
the contact information of the person to whom aquatic plants were distributed, and
the amount received for the aquatic plants.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following powers of a licensing officer may not be exercised with respect to a class of persons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to waive a requirement under this Division;
to set a different schedule under section 15 (3) [submission of harvest records and royalties].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not harvest wild aquatic plants that may be distributed to the public for human consumption unless the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a wild aquatic plant harvester licence,
is an employee, acting in the course of employment, of a person who holds a wild aquatic plant harvester licence,
is exempt under subsection (3) or is an employee, acting in the course of employment, of a person who is exempt under subsection (3), or
is exempt under subsection (5) or (6).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who possesses 100 kg of aquatic plants or more, measured while wet, is deemed to have harvested the aquatic plants for the purpose of distribution to the public for human consumption.
Subject to subsection (4), a person is exempt from the requirement to hold a wild aquatic plant harvester licence if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a licensing officer waives that requirement,
harvested aquatic plants will be used for an educational or experimental purpose only, and
harvested aquatic plants will not be further used for a commercial purpose.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is exempt, under subsection (3), from the requirement to hold a licence must comply with section 13 [harvest of aquatic plants] as if the person were a wild aquatic plant harvester.
A person is exempt from the requirement to hold a wild aquatic plant harvester licence if the person harvests wild aquatic plants only

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a food, social or ceremonial purpose,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: further to an aboriginal right, or
in accordance with a provision of a final agreement with a treaty first nation or the NisgÌ±a'a Final Agreement, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with all applicable NisgÌ±a'a laws or laws made by a treaty first nation, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is exempt from the requirement to hold a wild aquatic plant harvester licence if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a harvest agreement that applies to the person provides that a licence is not required, and
the person harvests wild aquatic plants only in accordance with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a harvest agreement, and
all applicable NisgÌ±a'a laws or laws made by a treaty first nation, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 7 (4) of the Act and subsection (2) of this section, an applicant for a wild aquatic plant harvester licence must include with the application

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a fee of $110, and
a harvest plan proposal, if required by a licensing officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is required under a harvest agreement to hold a wild aquatic plant harvester licence, the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must include with the application for the licence a fee and a harvest plan proposal in accordance with the terms and conditions of the harvest agreement, or
is exempt from the requirement to submit

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an application fee if the harvest agreement provides that no fee is payable for the licence, and
a harvest plan proposal if the harvest agreement provides that a licensing officer may not request a harvest plan proposal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For a licence to be issued with respect to the following year, an applicant must apply for the licence on or before October 1 unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a licensing officer waives this requirement, or
a harvest agreement provides otherwise.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In determining whether to issue a wild aquatic plant harvester licence, a licensing officer must consider the management of aquatic plant resources.

For the purpose of subsection (1) but subject to section 9 (2) (b) (ii) [application for wild aquatic plant harvester licence], a licensing officer may require an applicant to submit a harvest plan proposal.
A harvest plan proposal must include at least the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: scientific information, including data, respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the distribution and quantity of the aquatic plants to be harvested in the proposed harvest area, divided according to aquatic plant group and aquatic plant species, and
the environment and ecology of the proposed harvest area;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a description of the proposed method of harvesting aquatic plants and the equipment to be used;
a description, based on scientific information and including data, of the potential adverse effects of the proposed harvest on the environment and ecology of the proposed harvest area;
any additional information required by the licensing officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 7 (2) (d) of the Act but subject to the terms and conditions of an applicable harvest agreement, if any, a licensing officer may impose limits or conditions on a wild aquatic plant harvester licence with respect to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the geographic area within which harvesting of aquatic plants may occur;
the quantity of aquatic plants that may be harvested;
the aquatic plants that may be harvested, described by aquatic plant groups, aquatic plant species or both.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 7 (2) (d) of the Act or subsection (1) of this section, a licensing officer who receives a harvest plan proposal may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: impose limits or conditions on a wild aquatic plant harvester licence with respect to harvesting equipment, the methods of harvest or both, and
require the harvest plan proposal to be modified and implemented according to the licensing officer's directions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A wild aquatic plant harvester licence expires

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the date set by a licensing officer under section 7 (2) (d) of the Act, or
according to the terms and conditions of an applicable harvest agreement, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A licensing officer may not set a licence term under subsection (1) (a) for a period longer than 3 years.
In this section, holdfast means that part of an aquatic plant by which the aquatic plant is attached to the substrate.
A wild aquatic plant harvester must ensure that aquatic plants are not harvested under a wild aquatic plant harvester licence except in accordance with this section.
Unless permitted in writing by a licensing officer or under the terms and conditions of an applicable harvest agreement, if any, the following harvest methods are prohibited:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: harvesting by raking, dredging or diving;
harvesting by any method that impairs

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the regrowth of the aquatic plant, including practices that harvest the holdfast itself or strain, break or tear the aquatic plant from all or part of the holdfast, or
the integrity of the aquatic plant bed within the area permitted to be harvested;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: harvesting detached aquatic plants from the foreshore in any manner that disturbs or exposes the substrate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless permitted in writing by a licensing officer or under the terms and conditions of an applicable harvest agreement, if any, harvesting must be done by hand, using a sharp cutting instrument.
A wild aquatic plant harvester must keep records in accordance with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this section, or
the terms of an applicable harvest agreement, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A harvest record must include at least the following information with respect to each harvest made during the term of the licence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the licence number;
the date and location of the harvest;
the aquatic plant species harvested;
the weight of the harvest

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: divided according to aquatic plant species,
measured while the aquatic plants are wet, and
expressed in tonnes, to the nearest tenth of a tonne.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If no harvest was made during the term of the licence, the harvest record must include the licence number and a statement indicating that no harvest was made.
A distribution record must include at least the following information with respect to each delivery of aquatic plants distributed by the wild aquatic plant harvester:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the quantity, expressed in tonnes, of aquatic plants distributed;
the contact information of the person to whom aquatic plants were distributed;
the amount received for the aquatic plants.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Submission of harvest record and royalties

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the terms and conditions of an applicable harvest agreement, if any, a wild aquatic plant harvester must submit to a licensing officer, in accordance with this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the harvest records prepared under section 14 [wild aquatic plant harvester records], and
a royalty payment determined in accordance with subsection (4).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), harvest records and royalty payments must be submitted as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 10 days after harvesting under the licence ends or the licence expires, whichever is earliest;
if the term of the licence is for more than one year,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: before December 31 of the first year of the term and
annually after the first submission, until paragraph (a) applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 7 (2) (d) of the Act, a licensing officer may require harvest records and royalty payments to be submitted sooner or more often than would be required under subsectionÂ (2), and may set a schedule for this purpose.
With respect to each tonne or part of a tonne, measured while wet, of aquatic plants harvested from each aquatic plant group, the amount of the royalty payment owing is as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for aquatic plants within aquatic plant group 1, 2 or 5, $10;
for aquatic plants within aquatic plant group 3, 4 or 7 to 9, $50;
for aquatic plants within aquatic plant group 6, $100.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A commercial fisher must not distribute the commercial fisher's catch to a person unless the commercial fisher

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a fisher vendor licence and distributes the catch only

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to a person holding a licence or other authorization under a provincial food enactment, or
to a person directly from the vessel from which the catch was harvested,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is exempt under subsection (2), or
is an employee, acting in the course of employment, of a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A commercial fisher is exempt from the requirement to hold a fisher vendor licence if the commercial fisher distributes fish only as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to a fish receiver or a seafood processor;
to a person who holds a federal licence to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: possess, process, store or transport fish, or
operate a cold storage facility that stores frozen fish.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to section 7 (4) of the Act, an applicant for a fisher vendor licence must include with the application a fee ofÂ $30.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A fisher vendor licence expires on the date set by a licensing officer under sectionÂ 7Â (2) (d) of the Act.
A licensing officer may not set a licence term under subsection (1) for a period longer than one year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Part 6 requirements applicable to fisher vendors

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A fisher vendor must comply with the following provisions as if the fisher vendor were a seafood processor:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 32 (1) (b) [general construction requirements];
section 33 [washrooms and hand washing stations], unless only containers of fish are handled and not the fish themselves;
section 34 [maintenance of licensed facility];
section 35 (b) [pests];
section 36 [equipment and food contact surfaces];
section 37 [cold storage equipment];
section 38 [protection of food];
section 40 [temperature, water and ice standards];
section 42 (a) [sanitation];
section 43 [hygiene];
section 44 [illnesses];
section 45 [animals];
section 49 [no storage of unnecessary items].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a provision referred to in subsection (1) applies to an employee, the provision is deemed to also apply to the fisher vendor while the fisher vendor is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: present in the fisher vendor's licensed facility, or
personally engaging in activities under the fisher vendor's licence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A fisher vendor must keep records with respect to each delivery of fish distributed by the fisher vendor that include at least the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the contact information of the person to whom fish were distributed, if that person is a person described in section 16 (1) (a) (i) or (2) (a) or (b) [fisher vendor licence];
the date of distribution;
the quantity of fish distributed, divided according to species;
the amount received for fish distributed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not possess, store or transport fish the person receives directly from a commercial fisher and that may be distributed to the public for human consumption unless the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a fish receiver licence,
is exempt under subsection (2), or
is an employee, acting in the course of employment, of a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is exempt from the requirement to hold a fish receiver licence if one of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person holds a licence or other authorization under a provincial food enactment and receives fish directly from a fisher vendor;
the person holds a seafood processor licence;
the person holds a federal licence to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: possess, process, store or transport fish or aquatic plants, or
operate a cold storage facility that stores frozen fish.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to section 7 (4) of the Act, an applicant for a fish receiver licence must include with the application a fee as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to receive salmon, $230;
to receive fin fish other than salmon, $150;
to receive roe herring, $230;
to receive invertebrates, $150.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A fish receiver licence expires on the date set by a licensing officer under sectionÂ 7Â (2) (d) of the Act.
A licensing officer may not set a licence term under subsection (1) for a period longer than one year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Part 6 requirements applicable to fish receivers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A fish receiver must comply with the following provisions as if the fish receiver were a seafood processor:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 32 (1) (b), (2) (a) and (3) [general construction requirements];
section 33 [washrooms and hand washing stations], unless only containers of fish are handled and not the fish themselves;
section 34 [maintenance of licensed facility];
section 35 [pests], except that if the licensed facility is not fully enclosed, only section 35 (b) applies;
section 36 [equipment and food contact surfaces];
section 37 [cold storage equipment];
section 38 [protection of food];
section 40 [temperature, water and ice standards];
section 42 (a) [sanitation];
section 43 [hygiene];
section 44 [illnesses];
section 45 [animals];
section 46 (a) [storage of chemicals];
section 49 [no storage of unnecessary items].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a provision referred to in subsection (1) applies to an employee, the provision is deemed to also apply to the fish receiver while the fish receiver is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: present in the fish receiver's licensed facility, or
personally engaging in activities under the fish receiver's licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A fish receiver must keep records, in accordance with this section, with respect to each delivery of fish

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: received by the fish receiver, and
distributed by the fish receiver.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Records must include at least the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if applicable, the federal licence number of the person from whom fish were received;
the contact information of the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: from whom fish were received, or
to whom fish were distributed;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date and location of receipt or distribution;
the quantity of fish received or distributed, divided according to species and, if processed, manner of processing;
the amount paid or received for fish received or distributed.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: cultured fish means fish that have been raised domestically under a federal licence;
pestÂ means any animal, whether vertebrate or invertebrate, that is potentially harmful to the sanitary operation of a licensed facility;
sanitizeÂ means to treat equipment by any method that destroys disease-causing micro-organisms for the purpose of preventing fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food;
sport caught fish means fish that have been harvested

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under a tidal water sport fishing licence issued under section 17 of the British Columbia Sport Fishing Regulations, 1996 (Canada), or
in accordance with section 15 (1) of the Wildlife Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not process fish or aquatic plants, or operate a cold storage facility that stores frozen fish, that may be distributed to the public for human consumption unless the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a seafood processor licence,
is exempt under section 28 [exemptions from licence requirement], or
is an employee, acting in the course of employment, of a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, exempt means exempt, under this section, from the requirement to hold a seafood processor licence.
A commercial fisher is exempt if the commercial fisher

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only stuns, bleeds, heads, eviscerates, ices, freezes or packages fish, and
engages in the processing activities referred to in paragraph (a) only

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: while at sea and aboard the commercial fisher's own vessel, and
with respect to the commercial fisher's own catch.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A fish receiver is exempt if the fish receiver only ices fish received under that fish receiver's licence.

A person who holds a licence or other authorization under a provincial food enactment is exempt if the person processes fish or aquatic plants, or operates a cold storage facility that stores frozen fish, only in connection with the activities regulated under the enactment.
A person is exempt if the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only stuns, bleeds, heads, eviscerates, fillets, ices, freezes or packages sport caught fish, and
engages in the processing activities referred to in paragraph (a) only for the person who caught the fish.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is exempt if the person holds a federal licence to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: process fish or aquatic plants, or
operate a cold storage facility that stores frozen fish.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who raises cultured fish by freshwater aquaculture is exempt if the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only stuns, bleeds, heads, eviscerates, ices or packages the person's own cultured fish, and
distributes the cultured fish only

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to a person who holds a seafood processor licence, or
to the public from the place where the fish are raised, at a seasonal farmer's market or similar temporary location.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who raises cultured fish by marine aquaculture is exempt if the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only stuns, bleeds, or ices the person's own cultured fish, and
distributes the cultured fish only to a person who holds a federal licence to process fish.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is exempt under section 28 (6) must comply with all of the following as if the exempt person were a seafood processor:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Division 6 [Records Requirements] of this Part;
section 66 [reporting information to minister].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is exempt under section 28 (7) or (8) must comply with both of the following as if the exempt person were a fisher vendor:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 20 [fisher vendor records];
section 66.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 7 (4) of the Act, an applicant for a seafood processor licence must include with the application a fee as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to only freeze or store frozen fish,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: $420, if the cold storage facility has a capacity of more thanÂ 80Â m3, or
$110, if the cold storage facility has a capacity of 80Â m3 or less;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to process salmon by canning,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: $1 800, if 32.66 tonnes or more is intended to be packaged, or
$900, if less than 32.66 tonnes is intended to be packaged;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to process salmon, if paragraph (a), (b) or (e) does not apply, $640;
if paragraph (a) or (e) does not apply,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to process fin fish other than salmon or roe herring, $290,
to process roe herring, $640,
to process invertebrates, $290, and
to process freshwater fish, $50;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to process sport caught fish,Â $210;
to process aquatic plants, $210.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant must include with the application a copy of the design and construction plans, including specifications, as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if applying for a new seafood processor licence, for the facility to which the application relates;
if applying to renew a seafood processor licence, of any alterations made to the licensed facility during the most recent term of the licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant must submit a separate fee with respect to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each facility in which or on which the applicant intends to operate under the licence, whether or not all or part of the facility is also used by another person or for another purpose, and
each activity referred to in subsection (1) in which the applicant intends to engage under the licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor licence expires on the date set by a licensing officer under section 7 (2) (d) of the Act.
A licensing officer may not set a licence term under subsection (1) for a period longer than one year.
A seafood processor must ensure that all of the following requirements are met with respect to the seafood processor's licensed facility:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the licensed facility is designed so as to ensure that activities carried out under the licence will be carried out in a manner that prevents fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food;
the licensed facility is constructed from materials that are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: suitable for their intended purpose, and
durable, easily cleaned and free from any noxious or toxic substance;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is no direct access between the licensed facility and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: living quarters, or
areas in which activities are carried out that are incompatible with meeting the duty set out in section 38 [protection of food];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the licensed facility is of sound construction overall.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that the seafood processor's licensed facility is equipped with both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: artificial lighting adequate in intensity and designed or protected to permit activities carried out under the licence to be carried out in a manner that will prevent fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food;
ventilation equipment that prevents the accumulation of smoke, grease, water vapour and objectionable odours.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that the seafood processor's licensed facility is connected to, or that employees have ready access to, a waste disposal system that cannot cause fish and aquatic plants to become unsafe food.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that employees of the seafood processor's licensed facility have ready access to washrooms and hand washing stations that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are adequate in number for all employees,
have hot and cold running water, and
are equipped with soap in a dispenser and a method of hand drying that uses single service products.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that the seafood processor's licensed facility is maintained so as to ensure that fish and aquatic plants cannot become unsafe food.
A seafood processor must ensure that the seafood processor's licensed facility is constructed and maintained so as to be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: free, to the greatest extent possible, of pests,
free of conditions that lead to the harbouring or breeding of pests, and
protected against the entrance of pests.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that all equipment in the seafood processor's licensed facility meets all of the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the equipment is constructed from materials that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are durable and suitable for their intended purpose, and
ensure that food contact surfaces are easily cleaned and free from any noxious or toxic substance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the equipment is in good working order, and
the equipment is used in a manner that will prevent fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that refrigeration equipment in the seafood processor's licensed facility meets all of the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the equipment is adequate, in both type and capacity, to meet the needs of the persons carrying out activities under the licence;
the equipment is capable of maintaining temperatures necessary to comply with section 40 (1) [temperature standards];
the equipment is equipped with a device to measure temperature that is accurate to withinÂ 1C.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that the temperature inside refrigeration equipment in the seafood processor's licensed facility is measured and recorded at least once in each 24 hour period.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that the seafood processor's licensed facility is operated, and activities carried out under the licence are conducted, in a manner that will prevent fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: critical control point means a procedural step, when carrying out activities under a licence, at which an action can be taken to prevent, eliminate, or reduce to an acceptable level, the risk of fish and aquatic plants becoming unsafe food;
critical limitÂ means a threshold, limit or standard that must be met at a critical control point to ensure that fish and aquatic plants do not become unsafe food.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: develop and maintain a food safety plan in accordance with subsection (3);
ensure that the food safety plan is implemented in the seafood processor's licensed facility;
keep records respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the results of monitoring and verification activities under the food safety plan, and
the corrective actions that have been taken when critical limits have not been met;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep the food safety plan in a conspicuous location in the seafood processor's licensed facility;
make the food safety plan and the records referred to in paragraph (c) available to an inspector on request;
review the food safety plan, and change it if necessary,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at least annually, and
if any significant change is made to the construction or operation of the seafood processor's licensed facility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A food safety plan must be in writing and must identify all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: those hazards that may cause fish and aquatic plants to become unsafe food, and the measures needed to address those hazards;
the process and information used for the purpose of identifying the hazards and measures under paragraph (a);
based on the hazard analysis under paragraph (a), all critical control points and, for each critical control point,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the critical limit, and
procedures to monitor the critical control point and to determine whether the critical limit has been met;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a critical limit has not been met, corrective actions that must be taken to meet the critical limit or eliminate unsafe food;

verification procedures, including procedures, tests, sampling and other evaluative methods, to be taken to ensure that monitoring procedures under paragraph (c) (ii) and corrective actions under paragraph (d) are being carried out as intended;
the form of the records that must be kept under subsection (2) (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must change the seafood processor's food safety plan in accordance with the directions of an inspector.
A seafood processor must ensure that fish in the seafood processor's licensed facility are maintained as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of live fish, at a temperature and in other conditions suitable to the species of fish;
in the case of fresh fish, at a temperature of no less than 0C and no more than 4C;
in the case of frozen fish, at a temperature of -18C or less.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that water and ice used in the seafood processor's licensed facility for the purpose of carrying out activities under the licence is of adequate quality to prevent fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food.
A seafood processor must do all of the following with respect to the seafood processor's licensed facility:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: develop and maintain a sanitation plan in accordance with subsection (2);
ensure that the sanitation plan is implemented;
keep records respecting activities carried out for the purpose of implementing the sanitation plan;
make the sanitation plan and the records referred to in paragraph (c) available to an inspector on request.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A sanitation plan must be in writing and must identify all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cleaning and sanitizing requirements, with respect to the licensed facility and all equipment used in the licensed facility, necessary to keep fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food;
the cleaning and sanitizing agents, and pesticides, used in the licensed facility, including their concentrations, uses and storage requirements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must change the seafood processor's sanitation plan in accordance with the directions of an inspector.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that the seafood processor's licensed facility and the equipment used in the licensed facility are maintained in a condition that will prevent fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food, including ensuring that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: equipment is regularly sanitized, with food contact surfaces kept as free as possible of disease-causing micro-organisms, and
pest-proof containers for the disposal of refuse are readily accessible.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that employees, while in the seafood processor's licensed facility,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: wear clothing, footwear and coverings on their hands that is clean and appropriate to the activity in which employees are engaged,
exhibit cleanliness and good personal hygiene, and
do not engage in any activity that may cause fish and aquatic plants to become unsafe food.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that employees wash their hands as often as necessary to prevent fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food.

A seafood processor must ensure that persons do not use tobacco or vapour products, within the meaning of the Tobacco and Vapour Products Control Act, in any area of the licensee's licensed facility where fish or aquatic plants are processed, stored or distributed.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must not permit a person suspected to suffer from, or be the carrier of, an illness communicable through food to come into contact with any fish, aquatic plants or equipment in the licensee's licensed facility.
A seafood processor must ensure that live animals are not in or on the seafood processor's licensed facility, except as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a guide dog or a service dog within the meaning of the Guide Dog and Service Dog Act is permitted, except in any area in which fish or aquatic plants are processed or stored;
live fish may be kept as permitted by an inspector.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that chemicals, cleansers and similar agents are stored in the seafood processor's licensed facility

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a manner that cannot cause fish and aquatic plants to become unsafe food, and
in containers that are clearly labelled to identify the contents.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Storage of packaging, ingredients and additives

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that the following items, if stored in the seafood processor's licensed facility, are stored only in dedicated areas in the licensed facility:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: items to be used as packaging, including labels;
ingredients and additives used in processing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that items, ingredients and additives referred to in subsection (1) are each

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: stored in a manner that will protect them from conditions that may cause them to become damaged or altered in a manner that may cause fish and aquatic plants to become unsafe food, and
clearly identified with a label.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Storage of inedible products and fish offal
bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that unsafe food, fish offal and byproducts are stored in containers that are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: kept separate from fish, aquatic plants and products that may be distributed for human consumption, and
are clearly labelled as being unfit for human consumption.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that items that are not required for the carrying out of activities under the licence are not stored in or on the seafood processor's licensed facility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must not process fish or aquatic plants unless the fish or aquatic plants are received by the seafood processor from one of the following sources:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who holds a licence under this regulation with respect to the fish or aquatic plant, as applicable;
a person who holds a licence or other authorization under a provincial food enactment;
subject to subsection (2), a person who holds a federal licence to conduct activities in relation to food for public consumption;
a person having lawful authority to harvest the fish or aquatic plant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must not receive for processing cultured fish raised by marine aquaculture unless the cultured fish have been previously processed or held by a person holding a federal licence to process cultured fish.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A seafood processor must not process any lobster or crab that is dead before processing begins, unless the lobster or crab is being further processed after previous processing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies despite section 3 of the Fish Inspection Regulations (Canada).

A seafood processor must comply with all applicable requirements and prohibitions of the following provisions of the Fish Inspection Regulations (Canada) as if the seafood processor was a registered establishment within the meaning of that regulation:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 34;
section 35;
section 37;
section 38 (1);
section 39 (1);
section 40 (1);
section 42;
sections 47 to 50.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 49 of the Fish Inspection Regulations (Canada), the requirements of section 25 of that regulation also apply.
A seafood processor must not receive bivalve molluscs for processing unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the bivalve molluscs have been previously processed or held by a person holding a federal licence to process bivalve molluscs, and

the processed bivalve molluscs are in containers that are tagged according to the requirements of the Canadian Shellfish Sanitation Program Manual of Operations, made under section 15 (8) (c) of the Fish Inspection Regulations (Canada).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that shucked bivalve molluscs are packed for transport and distribution only in containers that are sealed in a manner that readily allows detection of any tampering.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Information on sport caught fish containers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that marks made in accordance with this section are legible, readily visible and permanent.
A seafood processor must ensure that each container of sport caught fish is marked with all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the species of fish in the container;
the name of the seafood processor, as shown on the seafood processor's licence, and the address of the seafood processor;
the date on which the fish were processed;
the words, "sport caught fish â not for sale".

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must ensure that each carton of containers of sport caught fish is marked with all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the information required under subsection (2) (b) and (d);
the name of the fisher who harvested the fish.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (2) (c), the date must be expressed in the format "year month day", as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the year must be expressed by using all 4 numerals that comprise the year;
the month must be expressed by using the code that corresponds to the month as shown in the table below:
the day must be expressed by using the 2 numerals that comprise the calendar date, with the first numeral being "0" if the calendar date is less than 10.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tracking system for sport caught fish

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor who processes sport caught fish must ensure that processed sport caught fish are distributed only to the fisher who harvested the fish.
For the purpose of subsection (1), a seafood processor must have in place a system that does all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: marks or otherwise identifies sport caught fish, on receipt for processing, in a manner that enables a person to readily determine the fisher of the sport caught fish;
maintains the mark or other identification throughout processing and until distribution;
verifies on distribution that the recipient of the processed sport caught fish is the fisher.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Seafood processor receipt and distribution records

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must keep records, in accordance with this section, with respect to each delivery of fish and aquatic plants

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: received by the seafood processor for processing, and
distributed by the seafood processor.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Records must include at least the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if applicable, the licence number or federal licence number of the person from whom fish or aquatic plants were received;
the contact information of the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: from whom fish or aquatic plants were received, or
to whom fish or aquatic plants were distributed;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date of receipt or transport for distribution;
the quantity of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: fish received or distributed, divided according to species and, once processed, manner of processing, and
aquatic plants received or distributed, divided according to aquatic plant group and aquatic plant species;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount paid or received for fish and aquatic plants received or distributed;
the contact information of the transporter that distributed the fish or aquatic plants.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor that distributes bivalve molluscs must do both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in addition to the information required under subsection (2), include the information contained on the tag referred to in section 53 (1) (b) [processing bivalve molluscs];
provide to a transporter of the bivalve molluscs a copy of the information referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: custom processing means the processing of fish and aquatic plants for the purpose of returning the fish and aquatic plants to the person from whom they were received;
processing for distribution means the processing of fish and aquatic plants for the purpose of distributing the fish and aquatic plants to persons other than the person from whom they were received.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A seafood processor must keep records, in accordance with this section, with respect to each calendar month or part of a calendar month the seafood processor is engaged in activities under the licence.
Employment records must include at least the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the number of employees, divided according to the type of activity in which those employees are primarily employed;
the number of employees engaged in custom processing activities, with those activities divided according to species.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Processing records must include at least the following information, divided according to custom processing activities and processing for distribution activities:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total quantity of fish and aquatic plants received by the seafood processor;
the total quantity of fish and aquatic plants processed by the seafood processor, divided according to species and manner of processing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A transporter must ensure that all equipment the transporter uses to transport fish and aquatic plants is constructed from materials that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are durable and suitable for their intended purpose, and
ensure that food contact surfaces are easily cleaned and free from any noxious or toxic substance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A transporter must ensure that all equipment the transporter uses to store fish and aquatic plants is constructed in a manner that protects the fish and aquatic plants from becoming unsafe food.
A transporter of fish must ensure that the temperature of fish being transported is maintained in accordance with section 40 (1) [temperature, water and ice standards].
A transporter of fish must comply with section 40 (2) as if the transporter were a seafood processor.
A transporter of live bivalve molluscs must carry during transport the record referred to in section 56 (3) (b) [seafood processor receipt and distribution records].
A transporter must provide the record referred to in section 56 (3) (b) to the person who receives the bivalve molluscs.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Must keep record of live bivalve molluscs
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who receives live bivalve molluscs from a transporter must do both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: add to the record received under section 60 (2) [live bivalve mollusc transporter records] a notation of the date on which the bivalve molluscs were received;
keep the record referred to in paragraph (a) for at least one year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No distribution of unlawfully processed aquatic plants
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not distribute, or offer to distribute, to the public for human consumption an aquatic plant that has been processed by a person other than a person who holds, or who is exempt from holding, a seafood processor licence.

Subject to section 14 [wild aquatic plant harvester records], a person who must keep a record of the quantity of fish or aquatic plants grown, harvested, received, distributed or transported, must express the quantity as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with respect to fish or aquatic plants grown, harvested or received, in kilograms or tonnes;
with respect to fish or aquatic plants distributed or transported, in kilograms, tonnes or as the number of cartons distributed, if a description is given of the

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: number of containers in each carton, and
the weight of each container.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to express amounts paid and received
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who must keep a record of the amount paid or received for fish and aquatic plants received or distributed, must express the amount in Canadian dollars.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Records to be kept for 3 years
bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to any provision to the contrary, a person who must keep records under this regulation must ensure that each record is kept for a period of at least 3 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2) and the terms of an applicable harvest agreement, if any, a person who must keep a record under this regulation, other than a transporter, must report to the minister the information, or a consolidation of the information, that the person must keep

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: annually, for the period beginning January 1 and ending December 31, and
as required by the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) (a) does not apply to the following records:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: harvest records prepared under section 14 [wild aquatic plant harvester records];
records respecting food safety plans prepared under section 39 [food safety plans];
records respecting sanitation plans prepared under section 41 [sanitation plans].

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 261/2016, s. 68.]
In this Schedule, the notation "spp." refers to all species within the genus preceding the notation.
The following species of aquatic plants are classed within group 1:
The following species of aquatic plants are classed within group 2:
The following species of aquatic plants are classed within group 3:
The following species of aquatic plants are classed within group 4:
The following species of aquatic plants are classed within group 5:
The following species of aquatic plants are classed within group 6:
The following species of aquatic plants are classed within group 7:
Salicornia spp. are classed within group 8.
All species of aquatic plants not classed within any of groups 1 to 8 are classed within group 9.

reg:content.reg:provisionsnote: [Provisions relevant to the enactment of this regulation: Fish and Seafood Act, S.B.C. 2015, c. 14, ss. 59, 60, 65 and 66]
